summary: This document is a compilation of news clips from July 9, 2019, primarily focused on the arrest and indictment of Jeffrey Epstein on federal sex trafficking charges in the Southern District of New York. It includes articles from various outlets detailing the allegations, the history of his 2008 plea deal in Florida, his connections to powerful figures, the search of his Manhattan mansion, and political reactions including Attorney General Barr's recusal decisions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Charged with sex trafficking and conspiracy for allegedly operating a network of underage girls from 2002-2005 from his homes in Manhattan and Palm Beach.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.context: As U.S. Attorney for Southern District of Florida in 2008, he approved a non-prosecution agreement for Epstein, now under DOJ review. Facing calls to resign.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.context: Announced the indictment against Epstein, argued he should be held without bail, and credited investigative journalism for assisting the case.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Announced he would not recuse himself from the new Epstein prosecution but would recuse from the DOJ review of the 2008 plea deal due to his former law firm's prior representation of Epstein.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Described as a friend of Epstein; his signed photograph was in Epstein's mansion; he took trips on Epstein's plane in 2002-2003.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Described as a former friend of Epstein; quoted in 2002 praising him; photographed with him at Mar-a-Lago.

persons.name: Leslie Wexner
persons.context: Epstein's mentor and primary client; originally purchased the Manhattan mansion Epstein lived in; severed ties with Epstein about a decade ago.

persons.name: Julie K. Brown
persons.context: Miami Herald reporter whose 2018 series 'Perversion of Justice' exposed Epstein's crimes and the plea deal, credited with reviving the case.

persons.name: Vicky Ward
persons.context: Wrote a 2003 Vanity Fair profile on Epstein; claims editor cut allegations from two young women; says Epstein threatened her during reporting.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as Epstein's girlfriend who helped recruit and reassure victims; daughter of Robert Maxwell.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned as a boldfaced name who hobnobbed with Epstein; the case is likely to cause him embarrassment.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Former Epstein lawyer who wrote to Pulitzer judges urging them not to reward Julie Brown's reporting.

persons.name: R. Couri Hay
persons.context: Invited by Epstein to view a mural in his mansion; declined to work for Epstein after a meeting about damage control.

persons.name: James Cayne
persons.context: Praised Epstein's skills at Bear Stearns; Epstein remained close to him and Alan Greenberg.

persons.name: Alan Greenberg
persons.context: Epstein taught his son at Dalton; Epstein later worked at Bear Stearns under him.

persons.name: Steve Hoffenberg
persons.context: Claimed to have taught Epstein financial tricks; was a Ponzi schemer; Epstein did work for him.

persons.name: Mimi Rocah
persons.context: Authored an opinion piece analyzing the new Epstein prosecution and potential outcomes.

persons.name: Graydon Carter
persons.context: Editor who cut allegations from Vicky Ward's 2003 Epstein profile; stated they lacked confidence in her reporting.

persons.name: Angel Ure√±a
persons.context: Issued statement clarifying Clinton's limited contacts with Epstein and trips on his plane.

persons.name: Spencer Kuvin
persons.context: Represented the 14-year-old girl who first reported Epstein in Florida; criticized the 2008 plea deal.

persons.name: Barry Krischer
persons.context: Former Florida State Attorney involved in the 2008 plea deal negotiations with Epstein's team.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: Member of Epstein's legal team who met with Alexander Acosta regarding the 2008 plea deal.

persons.name: Erika Kellerhals
persons.context: Lawyer in the Virgin Islands who handled the 2011 transfer of Epstein's Manhattan mansion.

persons.name: Rick Hirsch
persons.context: Miami Herald managing editor who commented on the impact of Julie Brown's reporting.

persons.name: Aminda Marques Gonzalez
persons.context: Miami Herald executive editor who discussed the origins of Brown's investigation.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, approved the 2008 non-prosecution agreement for Epstein, which is now under DOJ review.
Wexner was Epstein's mentor and primary client; Epstein managed his money and acquired his Manhattan mansion.
Maxwell was Epstein's girlfriend and alleged accomplice in recruiting and reassuring victims.
Clinton was a friend who took multiple trips on Epstein's plane and had his photo in Epstein's mansion.
Trump was a friend who praised Epstein in 2002 and was photographed with him at Mar-a-Lago.
Prince Andrew is mentioned as a boldfaced name who socialized with Epstein.
Dershowitz was part of Epstein's legal team during the Florida case.
Brown's investigative reporting for the Miami Herald exposed Epstein's crimes and the plea deal, leading to renewed scrutiny.
Ward profiled Epstein in 2003; she alleges he threatened her and her editor cut allegations from her story.
Barr recused himself from the DOJ review of Acosta's handling of the 2008 Epstein plea deal.
Barr recused from the 2008 plea deal review because his former law firm, Kirkland & Ellis, had represented Epstein in 2008.

events.title: Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey on federal sex trafficking charges.

events.title: Indictment Unsealed
events.description: A 14-page indictment was unsealed in SDNY charging Epstein with sex trafficking and conspiracy for crimes from 2002-2005.

events.title: Search of Manhattan Mansion
events.description: FBI and NYPD executed a search warrant at Epstein's Upper East Side townhouse, prying open the door and seizing sexually suggestive photographs, including of underage girls.

events.title: Florida Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty to state charges of soliciting prostitution from a minor, serving 13 months in a county jail with work release, avoiding federal charges, in a deal approved by Alexander Acosta.

events.title: Court Ruling on Victim Rights
events.description: A federal judge ruled that the 2008 plea deal violated the rights of Epstein's victims by not notifying them.

events.title: Miami Herald Series Published
events.description: Julie K. Brown's Miami Herald series 'Perversion of Justice' exposed Epstein's crimes and the plea deal, reviving public and legal interest.

events.title: Barr Recusal Decision
events.description: Attorney General William Barr announced he would not recuse from the new Epstein prosecution but would recuse from the DOJ review of the 2008 plea deal.

events.title: Alleged Sex Trafficking Operation
events.description: Epstein allegedly operated a sex trafficking ring, exploiting dozens of minor girls at his homes in Manhattan and Palm Beach.

locations: Little St. James Island, U.S. Virgin Islands (Epstein's private island)
Teterboro Airport, New Jersey (site of arrest)
Southern District of New York (prosecuting jurisdiction)
Southern District of Florida (2008 plea deal jurisdiction)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was indicted on federal sex trafficking and conspiracy charges for allegedly exploiting dozens of minor girls from 2002-2005.
The 2008 non-prosecution agreement in Florida, approved by then-U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta, allowed Epstein to avoid federal charges and served only 13 months in county jail.
A search of Epstein's Manhattan mansion on July 6, 2019, yielded hundreds or thousands of sexually suggestive photographs, some appearing to be of underage girls.
Attorney General William Barr recused himself from the DOJ review of the 2008 plea deal due to his former law firm's representation of Epstein, but will oversee the new prosecution.
Investigative journalism, particularly Julie K. Brown's Miami Herald series, is credited with reviving the case and leading to the new charges.
